posts.name: Ahmet Selim
posts.cooked:
Hello,

As I try to deploy code through this year’s radio, I see that deploy is successful. But robot doesn’t work except the joystick. Sys light is blinking in 1 Hz, so that means “unable to ping 10.xx.yy.4 (Field side IP)”. I had done pinging it several times with “ping 10.102.30.2” code in cmd (my team number is 10230) but it still didn’t solve the issue. I think if I solve this sys light issue, I can really deploy the code, because even if I connect the robot through driver station, also the ethernet cable blinks yellow and rio’s radio button doesn’t blink at all. How can I solve this issue? Let me know if you have any further questions.

Thank you
Just an FYI, I believe the router’s IP is at 10.xx.yy.1, and 10.xx.yy.2 is what to set the RoboRIO to when using a static IP.

posts.name: Carter Ryba
posts.cooked:
Are you actually able to deploy code through the radio? (you probably are I just havent)  I have always connected the usb-b connector to the rio and my computer and deployed it from there.

Just some good things to check: Does your rio have this years software on it? Does your radio have the most recent software on it? Is your radio wired up in the way from the vividhosting website? ( Wiring Your Radio | FIRST FRC Radio )

link_counts.title: Wiring Your Radio | FIRST FRC Radio

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked:
10.xx.yy.4 is the IP address of the gateway when connected to a field or when you have two radio’s bridged (one in AP mode and one in client/radio mode)

If you are running a single radio, it’s expected to not see 10.xx.yy.4.

posts.name: Ahmet Selim

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked:
Are you connected to the robot radio via ethernet or via the 2.4GHz wireless?

If you are unable to connect to the roboRIO via USB that suggests something might be misconfigured on the rio side.

Are you able to connect to the roboRIO web interface via USB (at 172.22.11.2) and get a screenshot of the network configuration?

The roboRIO and FRC ® tools use dynamic IP addresses ( DHCP) for network connectivity. This article describes steps for troubleshooting networking connectivity between your PC and your roboRIO Ping...

link_counts.title: roboRIO Network Troubleshooting — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Ahmet Selim
posts.cooked:
I connected via 2.4GHz. With 172.22.11.2, I couldn’t go to rio web interface, so I used “roboRIO-10230- FRC .local”, it showed this: image 977×808 32.7 KB

image 977×808 32.7 KB

image 977×808 32.7 KB

Is it okay if I have 0.0.0.0 on the ethernet, it doesn’t seem right

edit: sorry, this is the network configuration: image 753×767 13.2 KB

image 753×767 13.2 KB

image 753×767 13.2 KB

posts.name: Thad House
posts.cooked:
That 2nd one is USB, so if you don’t have USB connected it will show all 0’s.

As for the sys light at 1 Hz, that will only work if you have 2 radios, or are on the field. If you’re just connecting over 2.4 Ghz, or over wired, that will flash, and can safely be ignored.

The main 2 critical things are does the DS see the robot, and can you deploy code.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked:
172.22.11.2 will only work if you connect to the roboRIO via USB. Since you are connecting through the radio that won’t work.

Looks like your roboRIO is configured correctly, and since you said you are able to deploy code, everything looks to be working correctly on the networking side.
